title: WATCH: Coco Gauff's dad delivers inspiring courtside speech moments before she wins first WTA title
text:
The touching moment where Coco Gauff's father delivers a rousing courtside speech moments before her maiden WTA title has been revealed.

The 15-year-old from Florida beat 2017 French Open champion Jelena Ostapenko 6-3, 1-6, 6-2 to win the Upper Austria championships in Linz on Sunday.

And she needed some soothing words from her coach and dad, Corey, to help her over the line during the change of ends at 5-2 in the third and final set.

Coco Gauff received a timely and inspiring pep talk from her coach and father on Sunday

Corey Gauff issues his daughter with some advice as she closed in on her first WTA title

Gauff urged his 15-year-old daughter to relax' and 'take your mind to another place'

In a video, released by Eurosport, he says as he crouches down next to her chair: 'Just relax, you're not going to sprint to the finish line. We're going to walk to the finish line, ok?

'It's going to take trusting your shot, hitting your ball, trusting your serve, ok?

'Don't worry about what's going on on the sideline. Calm down. What I want you to do is take your mind to another place right now. Remember we talked about that?

'Take your mind to another place, take yourself to a practice match, just play. Don't think about negatives, just think about positives. You're in position, you're right where we want to be.

Gauff ended the changeover period by asking her coach what side she should hit to

'Take your mind to another place right now'



This was an amazing moment in the final set at @WTALinz



Terrific advice from @CocoGauff's coach and dad with the title within reach#CallMeCoco pic.twitter.com/eGwG6hSKGL — Eurosport UK (@Eurosport_UK) October 13, 2019

'Yesterday if you knew you had 5-2, you'd take that. You'd take that. You have 5-2, you're in control, she's got to compete.'

The teen sensation was clearly agitated as she closed in on her moment of triumph, and snapped at her dad asking for some tips.

'Just tell me which side do I need to hit to?', she asked.

'It doesn't matter. Hit through the court', he replied, to which she said, 'Just tell me something.'

He caved in, replying: 'Hit to the backhand, hit to the backhand hard.'

Gauff closed out the match to become the youngest player since the Czech Republic's Nicole Vaidisova in 2004 to win a maiden tour title, and only confirmed the immense promise she showed at Wimbledon and the US Open.

Gauff, who will now enter the world's top 75, actually lost in the final qualifying round for the Austrian tournament, but entered the draw as a 'lucky loser' thanks to a late withdrawal.
